conclusion: To find the magnitude of the Ampere force received by the wire, we need to consider the forces acting on each segment of the wire due to the magnetic fields.
The Ampere force on a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field is given by the formula: \( \vec{F} = I \vec{L} \times \vec{B} \).
\( I \) is the current, \( \vec{L} \) is the length vector of the wire segment, \( \vec{B} \) is the magnetic field vector.
Segment AB has length \( L \), current \( I \), and a magnetic field \( B \) perpendicular to the plane and pointing inward.

premise: Segment AB: Length \( L \), Current \( I \), Magnetic field \( B \) perpendicular to the plane and pointing inward.
conclusion: The force on segment AB is given by: \( \vec{F}_{AB} = I L B \sin(\theta) \) where \( \theta = 90^\circ \) and \( \sin(90^\circ) = 1 \). \( \vec{F}_{AB} = I L B \).
Segment BC has length \( L \), current \( I \), and a magnetic field \( B \) perpendicular to the plane and pointing outward.

premise: Segment BC: Length \( L \), Current \( I \), Magnetic field \( B \) perpendicular to the plane and pointing outward.
conclusion: The force on segment BC is given by: \( \vec{F}_{BC} = I L B \sin(\theta) \) where \( \theta = 90^\circ \) and \( \sin(90^\circ) = 1 \). \( \vec{F}_{BC} = I L B \).

premise: The direction of the force on segment AB is determined using the right-hand rule. Magnetic field is inward, current from A to B.
conclusion: The force on segment AB is directed to the left.

premise: The direction of the force on segment BC is determined using the right-hand rule. Magnetic field is outward, current from B to C.
conclusion: The force on segment BC is directed to the right.

premise: The forces on segments AB and BC are equal in magnitude but opposite in direction.
conclusion: The net force on the wire is zero.
